Job Description
What is the opportunity?
Wealth Management Data & AI is responsible for delivering a global data foundation and innovative AI capabilities across all of Wealth Management’s global businesses.
Complementing our existing Data & AI roadmap, we’re building an applied AI lab, with a mandate to explore breakthrough AI methods and turn them into testable prototypes and capabilities to support our 6,000 wealth management professionals globally.
We are looking to hire an awesome Applied AI Scientist to help us apply knowledge graphs and graph databases to wealth advisory. You’ll use skills and research background to explore and build graph-powered prototypes that will elevate the client experience and advisor productivity—reshaping the competitive landscape of wealth advisory services globally.
What will you do?
Design and build knowledge graph architectures that model complex wealth relationships, enabling reasoning capabilities beyond traditional ML approaches
Develop ontologies and graph schemas that capture nuanced domain knowledge, making expertise queryable and scalable
Lead projects that integrate knowledge graphs with large language models (GraphRAG, knowledge-grounded generation) to deliver contextually accurate and explainable advisor tools
Translate wealth management business needs into testable graph-based solutions, from proof-of-concept to testable prototypes
Stay current with advances in knowledge representation, graph neural networks, and semantic technologies, incorporating them into the lab’s toolbox
Contribute to a growing culture of innovation by experimenting boldly with high-risk, high-reward approaches
What do you need to succeed?
Must Have:
Passion for solving open problems in real-world contexts using knowledge representation, graph-based reasoning, and data-driven approaches in real-world contexts
Master’s degree (or equivalent) in computer science, AI/machine learning, quantitative psychology, or another quantitative field
4–8 years of experience in AI/ML/data science, including a combination of graduate training, academia, public sector, and/or industry experience
Hands-on experience designing graph data models and working with graph databases (Neo4j, Amazon Neptune, TigerGraph) and/or knowledge graph frameworks (RDF/OWL, property graphs, SPARKQL)
Proficiency in Python and common graph libraries (NetworkX, PyG, DGL) and common ML tools (NumPy, Faker, PyTorch, TensorFlow, GitHub, Streamlit)
Experience building proofs-of-concept and prototypes to demonstrate novel concepts in practical application contexts

Gen AI: Develop and deploy scalable production Gen AI systems for Gen AI models.

The Vector Institute is seeking Machine Learning Associates (MLAs) to join the FastLane MLA Program. Understand Business Case
 Work with the company and MLAs to frame the AI problem based on business needs; 
 Research and design effective AI solutions aligned with the company’s business goals, data readiness, and infrastructure constraints; and,

Develop Proof-of-Concept (POC)
 Preprocess data to meet the quality and format needs of the AI model or pipeline; 
 Develop, test, and evaluate models and pipelines to deliver robust, scalable AI solutions; 
 Deploy AI solutions on company-provided infrastructure, such as GCP, AWS, or Azure; 
 Refine and optimize the AI solution through iterative experimentation; and, 
 Rapidly design, develop, and deliver AI solutions tailored to the company’s use case. 
Deliver Business Value
 Engage in regular touchpoints with Vector and the company to align with business needs; 
 Utilize learning sessions and office hours to transfer knowledge and support the company’s AI adoption efforts; 
 Create project documentation, including a Showcase Day presentation, and Final Report; 
 Ensure seamless handover to the company through clear and well-documented deliverables; and, 
 Perform other duties as required to ensure project success.

 You are a student or recent graduate of an AI-focused Master’s or PhD program in Canada, or conducting research under the supervision of a Vector Institute Faculty Member. 
 You have completed at least one machine learning project involving design, development, and deployment in either an academic or professional setting. 
 You are proficient in Python programming. 
 You have knowledge of AI techniques related to Generative AI , such as prompt engineering, fine-tuning, autonomous agents, memory and tools integration. 
 You have hands-on experience with leading ML frameworks and tools commonly used in multimodal AI and agentic workflows, such as TensorFlow, PyTorch, OpenAI APIs or equivalent, Transformers library, LangChain, and Streamlit or Gardio . 
 You have prior experience deploying AI solutions in real-world or production environments. 
 You are available for the full duration of the cohort, with no more than 20-hours per week of other commitments if part-time, or no other ongoing commitments if full-time. 
NICE TO HAVE
 You have a portfolio of ML/AI projects across academic, professional, or personal contexts. 
 You have participated in rapid AI development settings such as hackathons, the AI4Good Lab, etc. 
 You have published research or conference papers related to artificial intelligence. 
 You achieved professional certifications related to ML/AI solution development. 
 You have received scholarships or awards in recognition of your work in AI. 
 You have experience with software development practices, tools, or workflows.

Description of the placement:
We are looking for a student interested in infectious disease epidemiology and machine learning methods who is seeking an opportunity to develop their epidemiologic and analytic skills. This project will focus on advancing machine learning methods for short-term (“nowcasting”) surveillance of SARS-CoV-2, influenza, and RSV activity in Ontario. The student will contribute to the development and evaluation of a range of algorithms—e.g., Random Forest, Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost)—using time series cross-validation to assess predictive performance. By improving the precision and reliability of respiratory virus forecasts, this initiative will enhance public health situational awareness and support timely, evidence-informed decisions in outbreak response, resource allocation, and health system planning.
Working with Scientists and staff from the Communicable Disease Control, Communicable Diseases, and Data Science and Analytics teams, the student will have the opportunity to develop analytic plans and undertake statistical analyses. The student may also contribute to the preparation of a report or manuscript.
This practicum is an ideal fit for a student with strong statistical analysis skills who wishes to gain experience in infectious disease epidemiology.
